item.title: Thank You WP Engine
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded: After watching the recent Mixergy interview with Jason Cohen as few weeks back I felt like I should write a quick thank you to WP Engine. Ever since we started Sennza I have been on the look out for a hosting company that knows WordPress back to front. We have had our fair share of war stories from hosting companies. Believe it or not, we once used Distribute IT before they died a painful death, but that's another story. After using upwards of 7 different hosting companies plus experiencing many other hosting environments with our clients I can say that for hosting WordPress websites, WP Engine is second to none. We only every use WordPress on our hosting so it's important that everything is optimised for this content management system. While I was watching the interview with Jason on Mixergy, he mentioned that they experienced rapid growth and had a few disgruntled customers towards the start of the year. During this high growth period we were moving one of our high traffic clients over to WP Engine. I wouldn't say we were disgruntled, we did have to shoot a few support tickets back and forth at this exact same time. I couldn't help but think that we were one of the customers he was talking about... When we first decided to use WP Engine we started with just one of our clients, naturally it was one that gets a significant amount of traffic. The website is also a membership website that is visited by tens of thousands of customers each day. One of the best things about WP Engine is that their server's cache websites heavily. Unfortunately for us the caching on the migrated site was not playing nicely with WP Engines' setup and thousands of members were locked of this website. After several support requests, Jason himself (the CEO of the company) jumped in to help sort out the problem! I can guarantee that any other hosting company would have given up with the caching problem we had initially! Actually, any other hosting company would have flat-out said that it's "not their problem". So hats off to WP Engine and thank you for helping us where no other hosting company would have. They even took notice of some feedback we'd provided about Random Posts widgets being able to be stored in a WordPress transient to reduce server load and allow some sites to still have these widgets. They even added a new feature in their dashboard to active the 'orderby' => 'rand' option in WordPress queries! I bet no other WordPress hosting company has ever done that in the past! Their service was so good that when we visited Austin Texas for SXSW this year we made it a must to drop by the WP Engine and say "Hello" (Picture above). All the team are extremely passionate and they are doing amazing things, I'm really keep to see where they are headed. Once again, Thank you WP Engine!

item.title: Developing Client Friendly Websites
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BGiKGLinf1k     At WordCamp Sydney 2012 I gave a talk entitled "There's More Than 1 Way To Skin a Theme" which was aimed at encouraging other developers to plan and develop websites in a more "client friendly" way. What I mean by this is developers should think more about how a client would use and manage their website, and less like how a developer would code it, after all, the client will be the one who uses the website long after the developer has finished. More often than not there are many way to develop the exact same feature for a website, so the planning that goes into the website can mean the difference between hours or minuties when it comes time to updating or editing your website. At Sennza we place a huge emphasis on making things as simple and easy as possible for the client to manage their website. If you have a website developed by us, we don't just think about how you will use your website now, but how you will use it into the future (well, as much as is possible at the time). Hopefully this talk gives you an insight into how we plan out a project for development at Sennza.  

Below are reference notes for the talk I gave:

In talk I covered some themes (no pun intended :) ) that we follow closely at Sennza to ensure we develop all of our WordPress websites in a client friendly way:
  • Marco Arment's post on Right v Pragmatic, is a great read for understanding how to approach problems from a different perspective.
  • What Would Core Do? is a talk by Jake Goldman at WordCamp Miami, and a great approach to take when you are developing a theme. There is no need to reinvent the wheel when it comes to WordPress, doing things like reskinning the WordPress dashboard can only confuse clients and create more work for you.
  • Plan out your content before you start ANY development. WordPress is a really powerful tool when it comes to managing content types and taxonomies so do be afraid to dive into these when developing a theme. If you are new to custom posts types have a look at this CPT generator as a starting point.
  • Content vs Context: Remember that you are building on a CMS, so the client can and will change content at any time. Label things that will make sense when the content eventually changes ie: Main Menu, Secondary Menu. 1st Footer Widget, 2nd Footer Widget.
  • For an easy way to list all sub pages of a parent we use a plugin called 'List Sub Pages Widget" which simply lists out the sub pages for the parent page that the sub page belongs to. (This is an internally developed plugin that we will make freely available shortly)
If you would like to uses some of the code examples that I mentioned in my talk you can find the code here:
  • CSS to add a PDF icon: https://gist.github.com/2848535
  • A WordPress widget to display all attachments to a post/page of a certain type: https://gist.github.com/1971133
  • For the video CPT example we used a plugin called Advanced Post Types Order
One of the side effects of this talk was that other developers came up to me and mentioned it was really interesting to hear another agencies perspective on development. If you are a developer and you think you tackle WordPress problems in a different way than most, we would love to hear from you!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome talk Lachie! Loved the "WWCD"!
Thanks Mat. Glad you liked WWCD, it's a great talk by Jake Goldman.

item.title: 2012 WordPress Predictions Followup
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
At the start of this year I made 5 Predictions about where I thought WordPress would be by the end of the year.
  1. WordPress gets an “App Store”
  2. WordPress + Social
  3. Better Media Experience
  4. WordPress Dominates the Web (Specifically 20% of top 1 million sites)
  5. Party Up Front (Front End Editing)
So let's see how I did...

1. WordPress gets an “App Store”: PASS

WordPress saw many "App Store" plugins released, namely WP Appstore, Renku, and to a lesser extent Woo Dojo and the ever-growing Jetpack. Unfortunately we didn't see an app store specifically powered by WordPress.com or WordPress.org finally an “app store”. Honestly after much thought, I'm having trouble seeing this ever happening for wp.org as an open platform like WordPress has vastly different dynamics compared to a closed platform like Apple's App Store. Because there were so many app store plugins released but not a WordPress.com or .org specific I'll going to give myself half points for this one.

2. WordPress + Social: FAIL

I expected WordPress to get much more social, in a Tumblr-like way. Alas, this did not happen. The closest we got to this was a feature in Jetpack called Notification, which allows you to receive comment notifications to all your WordPress.org and WordPress.com accounts no matter what website you are logged in on. There is no "global WordPress profile" that I would have liked, but the Jetpack plugin along with WordPress.com is getting closer to this.

3. Better Media Experience: PASS

With the release of WordPress 3.5 on Dec 11th, WordPress received a much needed and much requested upgrade to the way it handles media. This might seem like an obvious prediction in hindsight, but when this post was written a media upgrade was far from in sight, in fact some questioned if it would ever happen. Thankfully it did and I know that the core developers worked around the clock to make sure of this.

4. WordPress Dominates the Web (Specifically 20% of top 1 million sites): FAIL

When I made this prediction I knew this was definitely a long shot, I made it more out of hope than belief.  While WordPress has grown dramatically over the last year from 15.1 to 17.5% of the internet (if you can believe it), if did fall short of my ambitious 20% prediction. Although it fell short of my prediction, it's a long way from the "tiny" 8.5% of the internet when we first started Sennza.

5. Party Up Front (Front End Editing): PASS

I am going to give myself a pass for this one. Although I think WordPress has a long way to go in terms of integrating front end editing, with the release of WordPress 3.4 back in June 13th which included the Theme Customizer, front end editing in WordPress got a major boost from the lowly admin bar that you could use to switch between front end and back-end for editing. So all up for 2012 I scored  2.5/5 for my WordPress predictions. Here's hoping I can do a little better next year ;)

item.title: WordPress Adelaide Meetup
item.dc:creator: bronson
item.content:encoded:
I was lucky enough to head down to Adelaide for the first time last month for the second WordPress Adelaide Meetup on November 15.  Ivaylo Stamatov organised the first meetup down there and this time Rebecca Collins joined forces with Ivaylo to organised the biggest meetup yet! :) The Meetup was held at the Majoran Distillery which is the first co-working space in Adelaide. The Majoran Distillery has only been around since July 2012 and already it's proven to be so popular that the boys who run the space have had to start work on creating a co-working space that's 4x larger than the current space! I've worked in 2 co-working spaces over the last 2 years and I highly recommend them for both freelancers and small businesses who are chasing a fun and interesting office space rather than an isolated office.

What we covered at the Meetup

  • Intros and details about what happens at the Meetups -  Ivaylo and Rebecca
  • Who are you and how do you use WordPress? - Everyone in the room :)
  • WordPress in Australia & Around The Globe - Myself
  • WordPress Triva - Ivaylo and Rebecca

WordPress in Australia & Around The Globe

Rebecca suggested the topic "WordPress in Australia & Around The Globe" for my talk at the Meetup so that I could give the Meetup members a bit of an idea about the WordPress community in Australia, how to get involved and also how you can get involved in WordPress around the world. I've added the audio and slides of my talk at the Meetup below. Thanks to Ivaylo for capturing the slides and the audio at the Meetup! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkMxvugxGKM
WordPress In Australia & Around The Globe from Sennza Design

item.title: WordPress Theme Frameworks Explained
item.dc:creator: bronson
item.content:encoded:
http://youtu.be/OuMQ0YPJbgo This panel was recorded at WordCamp Sydney 2012 so that WordCamp attendees could learn how different WordPress developers make use of theme frameworks or starter themes for producing WordPress websites. This session gathers some of the WordPress theme development gurus who use theme frameworks or starter themes. We explain about why we use them, which frameworks we use, and their benefits and drawbacks in a Theme Development workflow. The panel includes (from left to right):
  • Dee Teal – The Web Princess who uses Genesis Framework by StudioPress
  • Tony Cosentino – who uses the Builder framework by iThemes
  • Peter Wilson from Floate Design Partners – who built his own ‘Big Red’ framework
  • Bronson Quick – who uses WordPress Twenty Eleven and _s (underscores) the starter theme developed by Automattic
The panel is chaired by Peter Bui from PB Web Development.

item.title: Using WordPress with Google App Engine
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
At the start of the year, Sennza were invited by Google to be part of the Trusted Tester program for PHP on Google App Engine. When it came to choosing a PHP application to showcase on App Engine, WordPress seemed like the obvious choice given that it is currently run on over 18% of the internet and is over 57% of the content management systems. Over the years we have had the chance to use WordPress on many different hosting environments so it was exciting to be able test a variety of different WordPress sites on App Engine.

During the testing process we found that running WordPress on Google’s infrastructure has many benefits, as you can take advantage of their world class infrastructure that will scale up and down based on your traffic demands.

Not long after this, Google asked us if we could help out with the development of a plugin that would make App Engine and WordPress work together with zero click configuration.

We have been working with Google to help create a WordPress plugin for App Engine that will work seamlessly with Google's infrastructure. This was definitely an exciting opportunity as it allowed us to look at parts of WordPress that can often be taken for granted.

The WordPress plugin will take care of the following Google App Engine features:

Uploads - When you upload media through WordPress it will be uploaded directly to your Google Cloud Storage bucket. GCS allows for multiple layers of redundancy as all data replicated to multiple data centers. This infrastructure is based on Google's own internal infrastructure for hosting and serving images.

Mail - When mail notifications are sent out through WordPress (such as user signup, password resets, comment moderation etc) they will now be sent out through Google’s mail servers as opposed to mail{} on most servers. This mail infrastructure is also used by other Google services and is trusted by most email providers, ensuring higher deliverability rates.

If you haven’t yet, head over and register for the limited preview here: https://gaeforphp.appspot.com/

Once you have done this, you can download the Google App Engine for WordPress plugin which is now available.

item.title: WordCamp San Francisco - Part 1
item.dc:creator: bronson
item.content:encoded:
The Sennza team packed their bags once again to head to the biggest and best WordCamp in the world: WordCamp San Francisco. We've almost overcome our jet lag as it takes about 22 hours straight in airports and aeroplanes to get to America from Brisbane but it's always worth it! We try to the make the most of our time here by balancing socialising alongside attending the amazing talks in both the WordCamp streams. I'll do a quick recap of our last couple of days so far for everyone who isn't lucky enough to be attending the conference.

Pre-Pre-WordCamp (Wednesday Night)

Lachlan and I headed into town to grab a quick burrito before we were going to catch up with Austin Gunter from WPEngine. We ended up taking a detour on the way to go to Local Edition because the wonderful Evan Solomon (ex-Automattician and now Medium superstar) DM'd me on Twitter to welcome us back to San Francisco. He was at Local Edition with Noel Tock, Michael Adams and Nikolay Bachiyski so we had to pop in to say G'Day. We had a great time hanging out and having 1 or 2 IPAs and whilst we were doing so we had the pleasure of having Austin and John James Jacoby pop in for a sneaky beverage as well. It was great to catch up with some old friends and make some new friends too!

Pre-WordCamp (Wednesday Night)

Last night we had a wonderful dinner with a few fellow Aussies and an American who works for an Aussie. https://twitter.com/rmccue/status/360616219939831809 I guess it does seems a little strange to catch up with Aussies when we're on the other side of the globe but as we're spread out across the country it's good for us to catch up in person and not online. Brent Shepherd has recently moved to San Francisco with his wonderful wife for the next 2 years so we definitely had to catch up with him and we haven't had a chance to see both Ben May and Paul Tevis from Alyte Creative for dinner since SXSW 2012!

WordCamp San Francisco - Day 1

As I write this recap I'm sitting in our apartment after a very entertaining and thoroughly enjoyable "Day 1" of WordCamp San Francisco. So I'll run through a quick recap of some of the talks I attended today.

Beyond the Default: Explorations and Experiments in BuddyPress - Tammie Lister

I can't explain how excited I was that the first talk was on BuddyPress! If you're not aware of what BuddyPress is, it's essentially a "social network in a box" and it really pushes WordPress to it's limits. If you're still under the impression that "WordPress is just for blogs" then check out this video. I've been a massive fan of BuddyPress and I was an early adopter of it and have followed it's changes over time and I am always looking for excuses to use it in client work. We've been lucky enough to use it on 3 clients sites so far and also one community site for the Australian WordPress Community (beta ;) ). Tammie did a wonderful talk on BuddyPress and went back through through time so that we could reflect on where BuddyPress began and what it's capable of today. I'm lucky enough to know all the ins and outs of BuddyPress and the core team have really lowered the barrier to entry for BuddyPress over the last few releases. Adding template compatibility to BuddyPress has been wonderful. My notes from Tammie's talk were as follows:
  • She created her first theme to spite BuddyPress! This might sound a little strange to people who are only just learning about BuddyPress but I could certainly relate with Tammie on this point. BuddyPress used to be rather difficult to theme back in the early days.  Creating a WordPress theme was much much easier than creating a BuddyPress theme in the early days!
  • Most users adopted the "kitchen sink" approach. By default BuddyPress used to turn on every feature, which meant that users would install BuddyPress and it would automatically activate activity streams, groups, friending and group forums. That meant that not only did an "out of the box" BuddyPress site mean that there was loads of work for the administrator to get their head around and configure, but there was also a massive learning curve for new users.
  • Start playing with BuddyPress! This was the biggest takeway from Tammie's talk. Tammie encouraged BuddyPress users to start experimenting with the look and feel of their BuddyPress site to make it look something other than BP-Default which is the default BuddyPress theme. Tammie has http://buddydesignlabs.com which is a home for all her BuddyPress experiments. Tammie encourages us to be a "User Interface explorer like Indiana Jones". Tammie says  "it's okay if we explore some caves and eat monkey brains", for those of you who weren't at the WordCamp, Tammie was encouraging people to explore different stylings for different BuddyPress components and it's perfectly fine if you fail in your experiments. Just make sure you give it a try!
  • Turtleshell by Paul Gibbs. Tammie brought up the project that inspired her to experiment more with different BuddyPress templates and components which not too many people know about and that's Paul Gibbs Turtleshell. Paul Gibbs does an amazing amount of coding both for BuddyPress and WordPress VIP.
  • "BuddyPress curious". Tammie really encourages people to make more BuddyPress plugins that restyle one component rather than the whole feature set and she also encourages BuddyPress themers to focuses on making a theme that puts focus on one area of BuddyPress rather than incorporating all the features.

Confident Commits, Delightful Deploys - Mark Jaquith

Somehow Mark managed to find the time to do a talk at WordCamp San Francisco even though he's one of the lead developers on WordPress 3.6 which is currently in Release Candidate 2 (test it please!). Mark covered some great points which were kind of embarrassing to reflect back on but they were all situations the majority of the audience have been in as they've transitioned from your "Mum & Dad" WordPress websites to the corporate websites. Embarrassing issues such as:
  • Have you ever had to retrieve content from Google's cache?
  • Have you ever had to throw a whole bunch of money at the server to avoid the "scaling question"?
  • Getting annoyed at the internet and saying something like "It's not my fault, DNS stuff is happening".
Mark shared some of his workflow tips some of which include:
  • Using Github as it's faster than SVN and has less disk usage. Mark even uses Github for WordPress core development and converts his Github commits into SVN patches.
  • Using http://beanstalkapp.com/ and http://deployhq.com/ for deployment.
  • Using https://github.com/markjaquith/WP-Stack/ and Capistrano-WP
  • Rolling your own deployment script "DIY Auto Deploy" with commands to rollback. Mark even wrote a deployment script that had 13 different swearwords for rolling back a deployment. e.g. 'deploy crap' would rollback a deployment.
  • Config files for Puppet and Chef should be in version control
  • Use http://www.vagrantup.com/ - You can "feel like a god" but destroying and creating server stacks. "Rise my minions!"

Writing Code as User Experience Design - Nikolay Bachiyski

I still remember the first talk I saw by Nikolay on WordPress.tv it was Unit Testing Will Change Your Life. My two takeaways from his talk were: 1) unit testing is amazing and 2) Nikolay is super smart and hilarious! I was lucky enough to see him at WordCamp San Francisco last year when he did his talk on 'Selected pieces from “Elements of Style” translated to code' and I very much enjoyed his outlook as somehow he manages to always think differently to most developers I've met in our industry. Needless to say, I wasn't going to miss his talk this year. I was incredibly engaged by Nikolay during his session because as always he was both informative and hilarious but the few points I took away were:
  • Developers spend: 20% writing/modifying code,  70% reading/understanding code and 10% writing new code. I honestly hadn't really fully considered how I spend my coding time but the more I reflected on these percentages the more I realised they were very accurate. As developers we tend to think we're pretty fast to code up a new feature and we'll have it "completed" in a few hours however we soon realise that we haven't tested it completely so we'll have to revisit the code and fix bugs then you've ended up spending twice the time fixing bugs than you have "completing the feature".
  • Personas As developers we have to think more about all the key stakeholders who use our code. We tend to think about two main types of people when we're coding, the 'user' and the 'next developer'. We need to think more about the other people who might encounter our code, and refactor our code and/or documentation for their experience.
  • Affordance - "An affordance is a quality of an object, or an environment, which allows an individual to perform an action. For example, a knob affords twisting, and perhaps pushing, while a cord affords pulling" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affordance. Nikolay referred to affordance to make us think about how our code base affects other functions so we can code in a better style. I think I've been lucky enough to learn this over the last couple of years as I've been using php classes as much as I can. They make me think about affordance every time I use them.
  • Experiment - You might've created something that you think is easy to use but it's always best to ask others for feedback on your code or some code that has been created by a group of people for others to use. Some people might find the code easy to use and follow whereas others might end up in this situation:
http://youtu.be/Ab7ykz7z1LU

What I Wish I Had Known Before Developing a WordPress Theme - Konstantin Kovshenin

Konstantin has always been a great resource for me over the years as I've leveled up my WordPress theming skills. I wanted to watch his talk to see what he reflected back on to see if I could relate and remember some of the hurdles I faced when I was learning how to code WordPress themes over the years. A few points Konstantin brought up during the talk were:
  • Not using query_posts when it's not required most of the time. He even got that passionate about it that he wrote the Stop query_posts plugin :)
  • Options should always be "decisions, not options" which is part of the WordPress Philosophy. It's always harder to deprecate options than add them!
  • Themes vs. Plugin Territory.  Konstantin wished everyone would code up plugins like Devin's Portfolio Post Type plugin rather than including that in a theme where a user will lose data when they switch their WordPress theme. :(
  • Listen to feedback. If a client or user offers you feedback then take it on board. Don't be arrogant and think that everything you've coded is perfect and doesn't need to be changed.
  • Cache your complex queries because they can be up to 10X faster!

Then we ended a fabulous day with an enjoyable dinner!

https://twitter.com/dimensionmedia/status/360938651263320065

Bring on WordCamp San Francisco Day 2!

item.title: Experiments - A new direction for WordPress development
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
From this year's State of the Word talk at WordCamp San Francisco the main takeaway for me is that WordPress will taking a whole new direction. In the past, WordPress release cycles have typically only looked forward 1 point release at a time. From an outsiders perspective it seems as though the features for the next release are decided just prior to starting development, development then starts and there is a lot of focus and iteration on these chosen features but anything outside this set aren't talked about until the next development cycle. This means that the future of WordPress is only 3 to 4 months forward. Based on Matt Mullenweg's State of the Word this year, this method is now being turned upside down. Features will be decoupled from releases and for the first time since I can remember there is talk about what will be happening out further that the very next release. 3.6 is close to finished but not released, yet there was mention of 3.7 and even 3.8 (Which then prompted discussion about 3.9 and 4.0). This makes a stark difference from last year's State of the Word where Matt talked about features that he would like to see, but with no timeline or commitment. The fact that WordPress is looking to the future was confirmed again when Andrew Nacin posted about a potential roadmap for taxonomy meta and post relationships  which discussed working on changes that would need to span over five or more releases. From what I have seen it's very rare that a feature in WordPress would span more than 1 release cycle, and it is potentially why the huge undertaking of the media library refresh that took place in 3.5 had been postponed for a long time. (It was talked about as far back as version 2.8) Not only were the plans for 3.7 and 3.8 revealed but it was also announced that they would be developed concurrently, the reason this can happens is because future features will start off as plugins before being brought into core. Developing a feature as a plugin allows for development to happen outside the normal release cycle, but it also allows for immediate feedback from a larger audience. Most people are more comfortable with installing a plugin than they are with patching core, and a plugin allows for feedback before the development cycle begins, not during or even towards the end as was the case with the now removed Post Formats feature.

The Post Formats dilemma:

During the development of 3.6 there were 2 main features that were removed. One was Post Formats and the other was a refresh to the icons Although the removal of the Post Formats feature from 3.6 was probably one of the most painful things for the lead developers of this release, it was one of the best things that could have ever happened to WordPress. It showed that features need planning and feedback before a release cycle starts. The icon refresh was pulled out of 3.6 fairly early and instead worked on a plugin called mp6, this proved to be a much faster way of iterating on a feature and proved the model for 'decoupling features from releases' going forward. It's an exciting new model and one that I'm looking forward to seeing develop over future WordPress updates.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
From what I have seen it's very rare that a feature in WordPress would span more than 1 release cycle
One of the places this is occurring is internal changes around slashing data, which is a holdout from old versions of WP. I believe the current plan is to spread those changes over the next 4 releases, with the first set of changes going in to 3.6.

Thanks for the example! I did preface it with "From what I have seen' just in case there was another example.
It's great to see and I hope more forward planning comes through in future development cycles.

item.title: Gamifying WordPress
item.dc:creator: bronson
item.content:encoded:
There was a WordPress themed Brisbane Web Design Meetup on Thursday so I put my hand up to talk about one of our recent projects for the University of Chicago. The project was an exciting one as it was an unusual use of WordPress. We used WordPress to create a site that had elements of gamification to encourage the users to revisit and interact with the WordPress site to gain points on a leaderboard. There were both online and offline challenges that the students had to complete to gain points. The "game" took place over 4 weeks and was a great success. The Achievements plugin by Paul Gibbs gave us the functionality base for the project and we extended it with some custom functionality. The video and slides from the talk are available below. http://youtu.be/ONiGZt155EM

Slides from Gamifying WordPress

item.title: 20 Percent
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
20 percent... or put another way, 1 in every 5.

As of a few days ago that is how many websites WordPress powers on the internet. What is even more staggering is that if you take out the websites that don't use a content management system, WordPress is just shy of 60% of the top 10 million websites that use a CMS. Not a bad statistic considering that it was only 3 years ago Sennza made the rally cry that "WordPress is not just for blogs, Dammit". At that time we were pretty excited that WordPress's market share was at 8.5%. How things have changed.     Last year I did go out on a limb and make the prediction that WordPress would indeed hit the 20% mark, unfortunately I was a little bit ambitious with my timeframe falling 9 months short of the actual date. In the end 20 percent is just a number. What gets me more excited is what's happening with WordPress as a platform and the community behind it. Something tells me we still have a bit more to go yet!

item.title: Solving Problems, It Isn't Just About the Solution
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
On the recent episode of the Critical Path podcast, Horace Dediu, a tech industry analyst made the following analogy:
The analyst should present the material in a way that other people can understand it, rather than just saying that I've cracked some problem...
He then goes on to say:
If you have solved something and you haven't been able to convince anybody else that it is solved, or that it is not of any use to anyone because they cannot absorb the solution then have you really done a great thing or not? For me there is no separation between the solution that is being worked on and it's presentation, these are actually co-dependant.
For Horace the data and it's visual representation are inseparable. You could say that as an industry analyst the spreadsheet is his "tool of the trade" yet the above is his justification for choosing Apple's lesser powerful 'Numbers' over Microsoft's 'power user' Excel. His explanation really spoke to me because this is exactly how we think about problems at Sennza. If we solve a problem, but it's not easy for our client to use then we really haven't solved the problem. If you look at a list of the top reasons that people say they use WordPress a reason that always makes it on that list is 'easy to use', yet no 2 WordPress setups are alike. There are tens of thousands of themes, tens of thousands of plugins, dozens of 'frameworks' and so many different ways that a developer could make use of WordPress. Every one of them approaching a certain problem in a different way. We recently got an email from a client that we had created a website for but hadn't heard from in a while. I don't paste this email here to toot our own horn, but as proof that this is something that is really important for us.
I just wanted to thank you for how you set up our website a couple of years ago. You were so helpful and the way you set up the website was so professionally done and so easy to use. I can see now that your website development is very intuitive and you have thought of everything.
For the marketing manager that sent me this email, their job isn't to 'learn how use WordPress' their job is to get content onto their website as easily as possible. This is what we strive for with every website or plugin that we build. If we solve a problem but it's not easy for our client to use then we really haven't solved the problem at all.

item.title: WordPress is Getting a New Admin Design
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
WordPress development has been full steam ahead over the last few months. It was only October 24th that saw 3.7 released and now it looks like we can expect 3.8 toward the end of December. WordPress 3.8 is  a little different to other releases in that it's changes are more visual, one of the headline features being a new admin design.

Why a new admin design?

First it's worth noting that the WordPress admin dashboard hasn't gotten a major design update since version 2.7 which was released December 2008. While the dashboard has had minor updates since then, 2.7 was a big visual change from 2.6. What the new design brings:
  • Responsive design, the WordPress dashboard is now optimised for mobile and tablets
  • Bigger typography for readability
  • Better contrast between your content and the navigation
  • Modern looking UI

Everything in its place

While the new admin in WordPress 3.8 looks different at first look glance, the important thing to remember is that everything  you are used to accessing in WordPress is in exactly the same place. Just with a nice new coat of paint. Before and After: [gallery columns="2" ids="1943,1944"] Responsive View: [gallery ids="1942,1939,1940"] Not a fan of black? The new dashboard comes with a few other colour options, including some lighter versions. You will be able to find these on your profile page to take them for a test drive.

Dashboard, Refined

The dashboard also received minor tweaks to remove some clutter with the main changes being grouping of certain items. The 3 news widgets have now been combined into just 1 and there is now an Activity panel that includes recent drafts, published posts and comments. 'QuickPress' has been renamed to Quick Draft and 'Right Now' has been renamed to Site Content. The new dashboard might be an initial shock when you first login but after a few views we think you will agree that it is a much need improvement to WordPress. We hope you like it as much as we do! Expect WordPress 3.8 to be release towards the end of December.

item.title: WordPress Predictions for 2014
item.dc:creator: lachlan
item.content:encoded:
As it is the season for prediction posts, I'm going to try my hand at some predictions for WordPress and the WordPress ecosystem in 2014. These will be equal parts fun, guesstimates and  wishful thinking. So without further ado:

1. Complete WYSIWYG editing.

What this will mean is the a user could edit content on their website without ever having to look at the WordPress admin. For more complex items such as eCommerce or relational data you will still have to use the WordPress dashboard, and for that type of editing the dashboard makes complete sense, but for editing text and media on posts and pages you will be able to do all this from the front end, no more guessing what a post will look like before publishing.

2. Goodbye TinyMCE.

TinyMCE will be replaced with something simpler and more medium like. I don't believe mark down will be a focus for WordPress, despite the popularity of Ghost.

3. Percentage of PHP in WordPress core will decrease.

We all know that WordPress is PHP based, however many of the headline features for WordPress over the last 12 months have been JavaScript heavy (The new media library as well as the customiser). The inclusion of Backbone.js and Underscore.js introduced in 3.5 will help lead the way for more JavaScript based features. As it stands the current percentage breakdown is as follows: PHP 69.3% JavaScript 18.2% CSS 12.5% (From the Github mirror repo as at 8th Jan)

4. WordPress API

WordPress will get an official JSON API and change the way that people use WordPress as an application framework. The API is already underway, but with its inclusion people will create unique interfaces and websites that allow people to enter and generate data where people will not even realise that it's powered by WordPress. The missing piece for WordPress to become a true application framework.

5. More Mobile.

The percentage of people using an app on mobile or tablet to post directly to WordPress will increase, I would even guess that we see alternatives to the default WordPress app that allow you to post to WordPress without visiting the dashboard (likely as a result of the WP-API). These figures may be hard to prove unless we see some stats, but Matt Mullenweg did mention stats in last years State of the Word so hopefully he will revist them next year. Break down here:

6. An IPO.

A major WordPress based company will list on the US stock exchange. The obvious one here would be Automattic, they have taken a lot of funding and are showing good growth in revenue. However I'm not going to limit this to Automattic as there could be another WordPress centric company that comes out of left field. Well thats it for my predictions. I'll see you all back here in 12 months to find out how I did! image by Tiago Gerken
